Graphical abstract It is challenging for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx by H2 (H2-SCR) in a wide temperature window due to the presence of excess oxygen. Herein, Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZrO2 and Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 were prepared and investigated for the H2-SCR of NOx. Compared to Pd/TiO2 and Pd/ZrO2, the H2-SCR activity of Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 was significantly improved, and the temperature window was notably broadened. The Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 catalyst exhibited an amorphous structure, along with a higher content of metallic Pd0 and surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) compared to Pd/TiO2 and Pd/ZrO2. H2-D2 exchange results suggested that H2 activation and dissociation was promoted over Pd/ZrO2-TiO2. In-situ DRIFTS analysis revealed that more NOx species and reactive NH3 were formed on Pd/ZrO2-TiO2. These factors collectively contributed to the significantly improved catalytic performance of Pd/ZrO2-TiO2. This study provides valuable insights into the rational design of highly active H2-SCR catalysts with a broad temperature window. Keywords Nitrogen oxides H2-SCR Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 catalyst In-situ DRIFTS Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The hydrogen-fueled internal combustion engine (H2-ICE) has attracted increasing attention as a promising pathway toward achieving carbon neutrality. Hydrogen provides carbon-free energy, and in principle, nitrogen oxides (NOx) are the only undesirable engine emissions [1]. As the regulations for the NOx emissions become more and more stringent, the control of NOx remains to be one of the challenging tasks [2]. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx by proper reducing agent has become an effective way to solve this problem, and the current commonly used reducing agent is NH3 [3,4]. However, many problems are encountered in NH3-SCR technology, such as NH3 slip, air heaters fouling and the poor catalytic activity below 200 ℃ [4]. Recently, H2-SCR is regarded as a highly promising approach due to its high catalytic activity at low temperature and the environmentally benign byproduct, H2O, which poses zero pollution to the environment. Therefore, H2-SCR is an attractive strategy for the removal of NOx [1,5–9]. For the H2-SCR of NOx, Pd-based catalysts have demonstrated to be promising and been intensive studied [2,10,11]. However, the poor low-temperature activity and the narrow activity temperature window have restricted its practical application. Considering the dynamic temperature of the exhaust, the development of the H2-SCR catalyst with high low-temperature activity and wide operating temperature window is desirable. In order to improve the catalytic activity of Pd-based catalysts, Hu et al. [10] have introduced Fe, Co and Cu to Pd/TiO2 catalyst and found both Fe and Co exhibited promoting effect. The role of the promoter is enhancing the formation of active monodentate nitrate species. The introduction of Mn to Pd/TiO2-Al2O3 catalyst led to a wider activity temperature window, however, the low-temperature activity is seldom increased [12]. Pd-doped aluminate spinel catalysts were also found to be active for the H2-SCR of NOx, and CoAl1.95Pd0.05O4 is more active than CuAl1.95Pd0.05O4 and ZnAl1.95Pd0.05O4 catalysts [13]. The modification of support is an effective measure for the noble metals remaining the active state. Li et al. [14] synthesized K2O-6TiO2 nanowires as a support for Pd in the H2-SCR reaction. Although the N2 selectivity of Pd/K2O-6TiO2 was higher than that of Pd/TiO2 catalyst, its activity decreased significantly, with a peak NOx conversion of only 41 %. In our previous work [15], Fe was introduced into TiO2 support and it has been found that Pd/FeTi catalyst exhibited higher activity than Pd/Ti and Pd/Fe, which was due to the strong interaction among Pd, Fe and Ti and new adsorbed NOx species on its surface. However, its activity above 200 ℃ still needs to be improved. Previous research reported that ZrO2 can be used as the support in H2-SCR catalyst and the activity of Pt/ZrO2 catalyst can be regulated by the introduction of Nb2O5 [16,17]. However, to the best of our knowledge, no research has been reported about the performance of Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 catalyst for the H2-SCR of NOx. Herein, we found that Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 exhibited superior H2-SCR activity in a wide temperature window. The cause of the promoting effect of co-presence of TiO2 and ZrO2 on Pd-based catalyst was elucidated by a series of characterizations and in situ DRIFTS analysis. This research would provide a deep understanding on the relationship between the structure and H2-SCR activity, which would guide an ingenious design of novel efficient H2-SCR catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Pd(NO3)2·2H2O(Pd ≥ 39.0 %) are purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. NH3·H2O solution (25 ∼ 28 %), Zr(NO3)4·5H2O(AR) and Ti(SO4)2(≥96.0 %) are purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All the gases (2.03 % NO/Ar, 3.96 % H2/Ar, 99.99 % Ar, 99.99 % O2) used were supplied by Beijing Haipu Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation ZrO2-TiO2 support (denoted as ZraTib, where a and b represent the molar ratio of Zr/Ti) were prepared by the hydrothermal method using Zr(NO3)2·5H2O and Ti(SO4)2 as precursors and NH3·H2O as the precipitator. For the preparation of Zr1Ti2, 20 mL of 0.5 mol/L Zr(NO3)2·5H2O and 20 mL of 1 mol/L Ti(SO4)2 solutions were thoroughly mixed. Subsequently, NH3·H2O was added dropwise to the mixed solution under continuous stirring until the pH reached 10. The resulting precipitate was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 120 ℃ for 12 h, and then calcined in air at 500 ℃ for 4 h. For comparison, ZrO2 and TiO2 support were also prepared by a similar method, but only a single precursor (Zr(NO3)2·5H2O or Ti(SO4)2) was employed in each case. Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZrO2 and Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 (denoted as Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr and Pd/ZraTib, respectively) catalysts with a 0.5 % Pd loading were obtained by impregnating 1 g of the corresponding support with 4.7 m L of a 0.01 mol/L Pd(NO3)2 solution. After impregnation, the samples were dried and subsequently calcined in air at 500 ℃ for 4 h. 2.3 Catalytic performance tests The catalytic performance of the studied catalysts was evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor using 0.2 g catalyst of 40–60 mesh. The composition of the feed was 2000 ppm NO, 1 % H2, 5 %H2O (when used), and 5 % O2 in Ar balance. The total flow rate was 200 mL min−1, corresponding to a space velocity of 52,000 h−1. The concentrations of the inlet and outlet gas were analyzed online by a chemiluminescence NO/NO2 analyzer (Thermo Scientific, model 42i-HL) and a Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer (Gasmet FTIR DX4000). The NOx conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated by the equations reported previously [12]. The reaction rate (k) and turnover frequency (TOF) for H2-SCR reaction were obtained using the differential reactor over which the NOx conversion was kept below 15 %. Before the kinetic experiments, the absence of mass transport resistances was checked (supporting information). (4) k ( μ mol/g · s) = F Y NOx X NOx m cat (5) T O F s - 1 = 106.4 F Y N O x X N O x L D m c a t where F is the total molar flow rate (mol s−1), YNOx is the molar fraction of NOx in the feed, XNOx is the conversion of NOx, L is the actual weight loading of Pd, D is the dispersion of Pd, mcat is the weight of catalyst (g) used in the reaction, and 106.4 is the molar mass of Pd (g mol−1). 2.4 Catalyst characterization The textual properties of the catalysts were obtained from N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms, which were measured on a Quantachrome Autosorb AS-1 system. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out using a Bruker D8 Advance system with Cu Kα radiation. Raman spectra were obtained on micro-Raman spectrometer (Renisaw, InVia) using 532 nm−1 line. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were accomplished on Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi using Mg Kα radiation, and the binding energy was calibrated using C 1 s (284.8 eV). CO pulse chemisorption was conducted using AutoChem1 ΙΙ 2920. The content of Pd was determined by a PerkinElmer Optima 5300 DV inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on a ChemiSorb 2720 adsorption instrument using the same procedure as described previously [12]. The H2-D2 exchange reaction was performed in a fixed-bed using 0.1 g catalyst. The catalyst was first pretreated in Ar flow at 200 °C for 60 min to remove hydroxyl species (see Fig. S1). After cooling to 125 °C, the gas flow was switched to H2-D2-Ar (2 %H2, 2 %D2, and Ar as balance gas) to start the H2-D2 exchange reaction. The flow rate is 40 mL/min and the relevant gases of H2, HD, and D2 were analyzed with an online Mass Spectrometer (MAX300-LG). In-situ DRIFT spectra was recorded on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 spectrometer, which was equipped with a high-temperature environmental cell and an MCT detector cooled with liquid N2. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst was pretreated at 400 ℃ under Ar flow at a rate of 100 mL/min to eliminate surface-adsorbed impurities, then cooled to the desired temperature. The background spectrum was collected in Ar flow and then subtracted from the sample spectrum. All the spectra were recorded by averaging 64 scans. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Physical structure analysis The textural properties of Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr and Pd/ZraTib are summarized in Table S1. Clearly, the synergistic integration of Zr and Ti significantly enhances the specific surface area. Meanwhile, the pore volume and size decreased. Among the studied catalysts Pd/Zr1Ti2 possessed the largest specific surface area, which could contribute to its H2-SCR activity [12]. XRD patterns of Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr and Pd/ZraTib catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 a. No peaks ascribed to Pd and PdO appeared over all the catalysts, which indicates Pd species is highly dispersed on the support [18,19]. For Pd/Ti, only anatase TiO2 [20] can be observed. While over Pd/Zr the peaks assigned to tetragonal phase and monoclinic phase of zirconia appeared [21]. In contrast, no obvious peak can be observed over Pd/ZraTib catalysts. This fact indicates a completely amorphous structure was formed, which could be due to the strong interaction between Zr and Ti. This phenomenon is primarily attributed to the atomic-level disorder within the lattice structure induced by the formation of mixed Zr-O-Ti bonds, which arises from the isovalent substitution of Zr4+ or Ti4+ cations into the host matrices (ZrO2 or TiO2) [22]. The resultant Zr-O-Ti bond hybridization serves as the predominant factor responsible for crystallinity degradation, as the incorporation of heteroatoms disrupts long-range periodic ordering and introduces localized lattice strain [23]. The strong interaction exerted a strong inhibiting effect on the crystallization of the TiO2 and ZrO2 phase, which contributed to decreasing the particle size and improving the specific surface area [24]. Raman analysis also demonstrated the strong interaction between Zr and Ti over Pd/ZraTib catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1b, over Pd/Ti catalyst, four Raman-active peaks can be observed at 144 cm−1 (Eg), 397 cm−1 (B1g), 516 cm−1 (A1g, B1g) and 639 cm−1 (Eg), all of which are the characteristic peaks of anatase phase TiO2 [25]. As for Pd/Zr, the peaks appeared at 177, 190, 537, 558, 615 and 638 cm−1 are ascribed to monoclinic zirconia, while the peak at 485 cm−1 can be attributed to tetragonal phase of zirconia [26]. This is in consistent with the XRD analysis. In the case of Pd/ZraTib catalysts, characteristic peaks related to zirconia were almost completely invisible. For Pd/Zr1Ti2, the peaks ascribed to anatase phase of TiO2 is weaker than that of Pd/TiO2, and the Raman peak showed a blueshift, which also suggests the strong interaction between Zr and Ti existed. 3.1.2 Chemical nature analysis XPS analysis was conducted to elucidate the chemical nature of Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr and Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalysts, and the results are exhibited in Fig. 2 . As illustrated in Fig. 2a, over Pd/Ti the XPS spectra of Pd 3d can be de-convoluted into two peaks at 342.4 and 337.1 eV, which are the typical characteristic peaks of Pd2+. While on Pd/Zr and Pd/Zr1Ti2, both the peaks assigned to metallic Pd0 (340.2 eV and 335 eV) and Pd2+ can be observed [27,28]. Over Pd/Zr1Ti2 the ratio of Pd0 (Pd0/(Pd0 + Pd2+)) is as high as 85.8 %, which is much higher than that over Pd/Zr (24.3 %). The presence of high proportion of Pd0 over Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst would contribute to the dissociation of H2 to form activated H [2], which then promoted the activation of NOx [29], thus favoring the H2-SCR reaction [30]. For Ti 2p patterns (Fig. 2b), two characteristic peaks appeared at 464.4 eV and 458.7 eV, both of which correspond to Ti4+ [31]. Compared with Pd/Ti, the two characteristic peaks were shifted to lower binding energy in the case of Pd/Zr1Ti2. Judged from the Zr3d XPS spectra (Fig. 2c), Zr was present in Zr4+ over Pd/Zr and Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalysts [32]. It is noted that on Pd/Zr1Ti2 the two characteristic peaks were shifted to higher binding energy than those of Pd/Zr. Correlating the binding energy changes of Pd and Ti as described above, the electron could be transferred from Zr to Pd and Ti, which indicates the co-presence of Zr and Ti led to the strong interaction among Pd, Ti and Zr species. O 1 s XPS spectra can be de-convoluted into two peaks for all the catalysts (Fig. 2d). The peak centered at 531.7 eV is attributed to surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oα), and the other one at 529.5 eV is assigned to lattice oxygen (Oβ) [12]. The concentration of Oα over Pd/Zr1Ti2 is 38.1 %, which is much higher than those of Pd/Ti (22.2 %) and Pd/Zr (29.7 %). The enhanced population of Oα plays a critical role in accelerating the oxidation of NO to NO2. As illustrated in Fig. S2, the Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst demonstrates higher activity for the NO oxidation to NO2. NO2 is more reactive than NO and would promote the H2-SCR of NOx [2,33]. H2-TPR profiles of the studied catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 a. Over all catalysts only one peak appeared, which was attributed to the reduction of PdO to Pd [34]. Compared to Pd/Zr and Pd/Ti, the reduction peaks over Pd/ZraTib catalysts shifted to lower temperature and the intensity was obviously reduced, which indicates that the reducibility of Pd/ZraTib was improved and the amount of PdO was decreased. As presented in Table S1, the size of Pd was decreased in the order of Pd/Zr1Ti1 > Pd/Zr1Ti2 > Pd/Zr2Ti1. While the reduction temperature was increased in the order of Pd/Zr1Ti2 < Pd/Zr1Ti1 < Pd/Zr2Ti1. The metal-support interaction could be strong due to the smallest size of Pd over Pd/Zr2Ti1, leading to the highest reduction temperature. And the optimal size of Pd over Pd/Zr1Ti2 could be contribute to the reduction. Similar phenomenon was also observed in the case of PdAu/TiO2 catalyst [35]. Among all the catalysts, the reduction temperature of Pd/Zr1Ti2 is the lowest and the intensity is the weakest, which suggests it possesses the highest reducibility and most metallic Pd, both of which are beneficial to the H2-SCR of NOx [2]. The hydrogen activation and dissociation are crucial for the reduction of NOx by H2 [2,9]. Therefore, the H2-D2 exchange reaction was conducted to reveal the H2 activation and dissociation ability over Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr, Pd/Zr1Ti2, Pd/Zr2Ti1 and Pd/Zr1Ti1 catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. 3b, HD generation rate among Pd/ZraTib catalyst was noticeably higher than those of Pd/Ti and Pd/Zr catalysts. This performance enhancement can be attributed to the electron transfer from Zr to Pd, which increases the proportion of metallic Pd0 species and consequently promotes hydrogen activation. Among the Pd/ZraTib catalysts, Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst exhibits the optimal Pd size, granting it superior hydrogen activation capability. The boosted H2 activation and dissociation over Pd/ZraTib catalyst would accelerate the H2-SCR of NOx. To further investigate the role of hydrogen spillover in the H2-SCR process, transient kinetics experiments were conducted. After the complete reaction of NO + O2 + H2, both H2 and O2 were removed from the feed gas. Since no additional hydrogen was introduced into the system, any further reduction of NOx could be attributed exclusively to hydrogen spillover on the support [36,37]. The transient kinetic responses for Pd/Zr1Ti2, Pd/Zr, and Pd/Ti are presented in Fig. 4 . Notably, after removing H2 and O2 from the feed gas, the NOx concentration at the outlet increased more slowly over Pd/Zr1Ti2 than over Pd/Zr and Pd/Ti. This suggests that more hydrogen was stored on Pd/Zr1Ti2, which subsequently underwent spillover from Pd to reduce NOx. Consequently, Pd/Zr1Ti2 required approximately 11 min to reach a new steady state, whereas the corresponding time lag was markedly shorter for Pd/Zr and Pd/Ti (5 min). Repetition of the experiment yielded consistent results across both transient cycles. These results demonstrate that greater H2 spillover occurs on the Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst. The enhanced H2 spillover promotes the progression of the H2-SCR reaction [33,37–39]. Additionally, we performed an experiment with a mixture of Pd/Zr1Ti2 and WO3 treated under H2 flow at 120 °C. The visible color change of the sample before and after treatment was employed to verify hydrogen spillover. Bulk WO3 reduction by gaseous H2 typically occurs above 400 °C, however, a distinct color change occurred after 10 min of H2 exposure in the case of the mixture of Pd/Zr1Ti2 and WO3 at 120 ℃ (see Fig. S3), providing strong evidence for hydrogen spillover from the Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst to reduce the WO3 [40]. 3.2 H2-SCR performance Fig. 5 exhibited the catalytic activities of Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr and Pd/ZraTib catalysts for H2-SCR reaction. Over Pd/Ti a maximum NOx conversion of 66 % was achieved at 150 ℃, and above 250 ℃ the NOx conversion was rapidly decreased to less than 30 %. Zr/Ti is more active than Pd/Ti above 200 ℃, however, its low temperature activity is poor. In contrast, Pd/ZraTib catalyst exhibited remarkably higher activity than both Pd/Zr and Pd/Ti, with Pd/Zr1Ti2 being the most active. The optimal Pd size and the strongest ability for the H2 activation over Pd/Zr1Ti2 could account for its highest activity. For Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst, a NOx conversion as high as 95 % was achieved even at 125 ℃, and the NOx conversion remained above 90 % in a wide temperature range (125–300 ℃). As shown in Fig. S4, the N2 selectivities of Pd/ZraTib catalysts were also higher than those of Pd/Zr and Pd/Ti catalysts. The used Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst exhibited similar H2-SCR activity to the fresh catalyst, suggesting that the chemical state of Pd remains largely unchanged under reaction conditions (Fig. S5). The effect of H2O on the H2-SCR activities of Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr, and Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalysts was shown in Fig. 6 . Notably, the presence of H2O leads to the enhanced H2-SCR activities of both Pd/Ti and Pd/Zr catalysts. Similar promoting effect of H2O has also been observed by Efstathiou et al. [6]. This improvement could be due to the dissociation of adsorbed H2O on the catalyst surfaces, which increases the H-reservoir necessary for the reduction of NOx [6,41]. In contrast, the activity of Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst is decreased upon introducing of H2O. The negative effect of water vapor on Pd/Zr1Ti2 can be ascribed to the competitive adsorption between H2O and NOx on Pd [42]. Notably, Pd/Zr1Ti2 is still more active than Pd/Ti and Pd/Zr in the presence of H2O. From Fig. S6, it can be seen that the presence of H2O leads to the decreased N2 selectivity of Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst. The turnover frequencies (TOFs) over Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr and Pd/ZraTib catalysts have been calculated and the results are shown in Fig. 7 a. Both the TOFs over Pd/Ti and Pd/Zr catalysts are very low. In contrast, the TOFs over Pd/ZraTib catalysts are increased significantly. At 170 ℃, TOFs are 14.5 × 10-3 s−1, 8.4 × 10-3 s−1, and 6.5 × 10-3 s−1 for Pd/Zr1Ti2, Pd/Zr1Ti1 and Pd/Zr2Ti1, respectively. To demonstrate the superior performance of our synthesized catalysts, a comparison with Pt and Pd-based catalysts is summarized in Table S2. Under the same reaction conditions, the Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst exhibits a significantly higher TOF than other catalyst reported previously, demonstrating its exceptional intrinsic activity. Therefore, the results from the present work are promising. Fig. 7b illustrates the temperature dependence of H2-SCR reaction rate over these catalysts. The apparent activation energy (Ea) is increased in the order of Pd/Zr1Ti2 (51.4 kJ/mol) < Pd/Zr1Ti1(57.9 kJ/mol) < Pd/Zr2Ti1 (58.7 kJ/mol) < Pd/Zr (69.9 kJ/mol) < Pd/Ti (78.2 kJ/mol). Evidently, the Ea for Pd/ZraTib catalysts are lower than those of Pd/Ti and Pd/Zr catalysts. For the Pd/ZraTib catalysts, the size of Pd was decreased in the order of Pd/Zr1Ti1 > Pd/Zr1Ti2 > Pd/Zr2Ti1, the optimal particle size of Pd could contributes to the H2 activation(see Fig. 3b), thus leading to the lowest Ea of Pd/Zr1Ti2. 3.3 In situ DRIFTS studies 3.3.1 CO adsorption In situ DRIFTS analysis of CO adsorption was further conducted to reveal the chemical changes of Pd due to the co-presence of Ti and Zr. As illustrated in Fig. S7, the peaks at high wavenumbers (2200–2100 cm−1) can be attributed to CO adsorbed on Pd2+, and the other at low wavenumbers can be assigned to two-fold bound (2000–1920 cm−1) and three-fold bound (1920–1830 cm−1) CO on metallic Pd [43,44]. Obviously, over Pd/Ti only two weak peaks appeared at 2168 and 2113 cm−1, which indicates Pd existed in the form of Pd2+. However, on Pd/Zr and Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalysts, noticeable peaks in low wavenumbers region can be observed (1945 and 1930 cm−1, respectively), which means metallic Pd was present over both catalysts. The stronger peaks on Pd/Zr1Ti2 than that on Pd/Zr indicates more metallic Pd existed due to the co-presence of Zr and Ti. In addition, a red shift is observed. This could result from a remarkable enhancement in d orbital electron density due to the charge-transfer from Zr to Pd, which led to a stronger electronic back-donation to 2p* molecular orbitals of CO [45]. 3.3.2 Co-adsorption of NO + O2 Fig. 8 exhibited the DRIFT spectra of NO + O2 adsorption on Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr and Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalysts. As seen in Fig. 8a, over Pd/Ti a series of characteristic peaks appeared at 1884, 1835, 1613, 1581, 1500, 1294 and 1240 cm−1, which are ascribed to symmetric stretching vibrations of (NO)2 dimers on Pd (1884 cm−1) [46], N=O symmetric stretch of Pd2+–NO nitrosyl (1835 cm−1) [47], adsorbed NO2 (1613 cm−1) [48], bidentate nitrate (1581 cm−1) [49], monodendate nitrate (1500 cm−1) [50], chelating nitrite (1294 cm−1) [51] and bridged nitrate (1240 cm−1) [52], respectively. The intensities of these peaks gradually decreased with increasing temperature and totally disappeared at 300 ℃. Over Pd/Zr catalyst (Fig. 8b), peaks related to adsorbed NO2 (1625 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1591 cm−1), monodendate nitrate (1523 cm−1), chelating nitrite (1292 cm−1) and bridged nitrate (1230 cm−1) appeared. Compared with Pd/Ti, characteristic peaks on Pd/Zr are still obvious above 250 ℃, which could account for its higher activity at high temperature. As illustrated in Fig. 8c, the intensities of all the peaks over Pd/Zr1Ti2 are much stronger than those of Pd/Ti, and below 200 ℃ the intensity of the peak attributed to NO2 is also higher than that over Pd/Zr. This indicates over Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst more NOx would be adsorbed and activated. 3.3.3 Transient reaction study In order to reveal the reactivity of adsorbed NOx species on Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr and Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalysts, the dynamic changes of in-situ DRIFT were studied and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . Clearly, after exposed in NO + O2 for 60 min at 150 ℃, the characteristic peaks of Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst were the strongest, which means that surface of Pd/Zr1Ti2 absorbs the most NOx species. For Pd/Ti, after the gas flow was switched from NO + O2 to H2, the peaks at 1884, 1835, 1613, 1581 and 1294 cm−1 quickly disappeared in 5 min. At the same time, new peaks appeared at 1431, 1325 and 1266 cm−1, which are assigned to NH4 + species adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (1431 cm−1) [53,54], NH3 on Lewis acid sites (1325 cm−1) [53], and the deformation species of adsorbed NH3 (1266 cm−1), respectively [52,54,55]. When the gas is switched back to NO + O2 again, peaks at 1431, 1325 and 1266 cm−1 disappeared and the initial characteristic peak emerged again, indicating that NH4 + and NH3 species are active intermediates in the reaction. Over Pd/Zr the peaks at 1625 and 1230 cm−1 gradually decrease with the increase in reaction time, yet they do not fully disappear even after 60 min. (Fig. 9b). What’s more, the characteristic peaks at 1591, 1523 and 1292 cm−1 were almost unchanged, which means the adsorbed NOx is not so reactive. From Fig. 9c, it can be seen that peaks centered at 1618, 1584 and 1235 cm−1 totally disappeared within 5 min. After 10 min, new peak appeared at 1183 cm−1 appeared which is attributed to NH3 species adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [36]. When switch the gas to NO + O2 again, the peak assigned to NH3 species disappeared, which means it is reactive in the H2-SCR process. Correlated Figs. 8 and 9, it can be seen more NOx was adsorbed and activated on Pd/Zr1Ti2, and they are highly reactive species in the reduction of NOx. Above 250 ℃，although the intensities of the peaks related to the NOx over Pd/Zr are higher than those of Pd/Zr1Ti2, the lower reactivity over Pd/Zr leads to its lower NOx conversion. The chemical nature of noble metal significantly influences H2-SCR activity [2,9]. Wen et al. [56] found that metallic Pd is considerably more active than Pd2+. In the case of Pd-Ir/TiO2 catalyst, the interaction between Pd and Ir induced the formation of Pd0, resulting in high SCR activity [57]. Over Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst, the strong interaction among Pd, Zr and Ti led to the formation of Pd0 with high ratio. Pd0 plays a critical role in promoting the activation and dissociation of H2 (Fig. 3b), enhanced dissociation would lead to increased surface coverage of H on the catalyst surface, which is also essential for enhancing H2-SCR activity [37,39]. In addition, Pd0 promote the dissociation of H2 and H-spillover from Pd to the support [35], thus facilitating the NOx reduction [37,41]. Besides the H2 activation, NOx adsorption and activation are also key factors governing the reduction activity [12]. In situ DRIFTS analysis reveals characteristic adsorption bands corresponding to reactive NOx species on the catalyst surface: adsorbed NO2 (1613 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1581 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1500 cm−1), and bridged nitrate (1240 cm−1). Upon H2 introduction to the NOx-pre-adsorbed Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst, all adsorbed NOx species disappear within 5 min, confirming their dynamic participation in the H2-SCR reaction. This observation highlights that NOx adsorption/activation is critical factor governing catalytic reduction efficiency. Notably, the Pd/Zr1Ti2 catalyst exhibits superior NOx adsorption capacity and generates more reactive intermediates compared to Pd/Zr and Pd/Ti counterparts. Therefore, the co-presence of Zr and Ti resulted in the formation of active Pd0, which not only contribute to the activation of H2 and its spillover, but also effectively enhancing the adsorption and activation of NOx. Based on the above exploration, the reaction mechanism for the H2-SCR of NOx on Pd/ZraTib catalyst has been proposed (seen in Fig. 10 ). Since H2 is activated on the surface of Pd, it is dissociated into H, which spilled over from Pd to the Zr-Ti support. On the other hand, NO and O2 were activated to form nitrate species such as NO2, bidentate nitrate, monodendate nitrate and bridged nitrate. These species could be located on Zr-Ti support and the interface of Pd and Zr-Ti. These nitrate species are reactive and easily react with activated H to form N2 and H2O. Meanwhile, the adsorbed NO can react with activated H and generate active intermediate species NH3. NH3 can effectively reduce the adsorbed NOx and convert it into N2 following the NH3-SCR reaction [58]. Therefore, NOx was efficiently reduced by H2 and in-situ formed NH3 species. 4 Conclusions Pd/Ti, Pd/Zr, and Pd/ZraTib with varying molar ratios were investigated for the H2-SCR of NOx in the presence of oxygen. The Pd catalyst supported on the ZrO2-TiO2 composite oxide exhibited significantly enhanced NOx conversion and a remarkably broadened temperature window. Among the different Pd/ZraTib catalysts, Pd/Zr1Ti2 demonstrated the highest catalytic activity. The synergistic effect among Pd, Zr and Ti species facilitated the formation of more active metallic Pd sites, which not only promoted the activation and dissociation of H2, but also contribute to the formation of more active adsorbed NOx species and NH3. As a result, the reduction of NOx over Pd/ZraTib was significantly enhanced. The present work shed light on the rational design of highly active H2-SCR catalyst with broad temperature window. coredata.dc:description: It is challenging for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx by H2 (H2-SCR) in a wide temperature window due to the presence of excess oxygen. Herein, Pd/TiO2, Pd/ZrO2 and Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 were prepared and investigated for the H2-SCR of NOx. Compared to Pd/TiO2 and Pd/ZrO2, the H2-SCR activity of Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 was significantly improved, and the temperature window was notably broadened. The Pd/ZrO2-TiO2 catalyst exhibited an amorphous structure, along with a higher content of metallic Pd0 and surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) compared to Pd/TiO2 and Pd/ZrO2. H2-D2 exchange results suggested that H2 activation and dissociation was promoted over Pd/ZrO2-TiO2. In-situ DRIFTS analysis revealed that more NOx species and reactive NH3 were formed on Pd/ZrO2-TiO2. These factors collectively contributed to the significantly improved catalytic performance of Pd/ZrO2-TiO2. This study provides valuable insights into the rational design of highly active H2-SCR catalysts with a broad temperature window.
